list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Prove that the sum of three consecutive positive integers is divisible
by $3$.
list.markScheme:
Let $n,n+1$ and $n+2$ be three consecutive positive integers for
some $n∈Z+$.
The sum of the three integers is
$$$n+(n+1)+(n+2)​=3n+3=3(n+1)[multiple of 3]​$$$
Hence the sum of three consecutive positive integers is divisible by
$3$.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Consider two consecutive positive integers, $k$ and $k+1$.
Show that the difference of their squares is equal to the sum of the two
integers.
list.markScheme:
The difference of the squares of $k$ and $k+1$ is
$$$(k+1)2−k2​=k2+2k+1−k2=2k+1=k+(k+1)[sum of k and k+1]​$$$
Hence the difference of the squares of two consecutive positive integers
is equal to their sum.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
The product of three consecutive integers is increased by the middle
integer.
Prove that the result is a perfect cube.
list.markScheme:
Let $n−1,n$ and $n+1$ be three consecutive integers for some
$n∈Z$.
The product of these three integers is
$$$(n−1)×n×(n+1)​=n×(n2−1)=n3−n​$$$
If this product is
increased by the middle integer, $n$, then the result would be
$$$(n3−n)+n​=n3[perfect cube]​$$$
Hence the result of increasing the product of three consecutive integers
by the middle integer is a perfect cube.

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Show that $(2n−1)3+(2n+1)3=16n3+12n$ for $n∈Z$.
[3]



Hence, or otherwise, prove that the sum of the cubes of any two
consecutive odd integers is divisible by four. [3]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$(2n−1)3​=(2n)3−3(2n)2+3(2n)−1=8n3−12n2+6n−1​$$$
and
$$$(2n+1)3​=(2n)3+3(2n)2+3(2n)+1=8n3+12n2+6n+1​$$$
Summing our expressions for $(2n−1)3$ and $(2n+1)3$, we get
$$$(2n−1)3+(2n+1)3​=8n3−12n2+6n−1​+8n3+12n2+6n+1​​$$$
Hence we get
$$$(2n−1)3+(2n+1)3=16n3+12n​​$$$


Let $2n−1$ and $2n+1$ be two consecutive odd integers for some
$n∈Z$.
The sum of the cubes of $2n−1$ and $2n+1$ is
$$$(2n−1)3+(2n+1)3​=16n3+12n[by part (a)]=4n(4n2+3)[multiple of 4]​$$$
Hence the sum of the cubes of any two consecutive odd integers is
divisible by four.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Using mathematical induction, prove that
$12+22+⋯+n2=6n(n+1)(2n+1)​$ for all
$n∈Z+$.
list.markScheme:
Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$12+22+⋯+n2=6n(n+1)(2n+1)​[for n∈Z+]​$$$
Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.
Base case. For $n=1$, we have
$$$6(1)(1+1)(2(1)+1)​​=6(1)(2)(3)​=1=12​$$$
Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k≥1$. In other words, we assume that
$$$12+22+⋯+k2=6k(k+1)(2k+1)​(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that
$$$12+22+⋯+k2+(k+1)2=6(k+1)(k+2)(2k+3)​(1)​$$$
From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain
$$$12+22+⋯+k2+(k+1)2​=[12+22+⋯+k2]+(k+1)2=6k(k+1)(2k+1)​+(k+1)2[by (IH)]=6k(k+1)(2k+1)+6(k+1)2​=6(k+1)[k(2k+1)+6(k+1)]​=6(k+1)[2k2+7k+6]​=6(k+1)(k+2)(2k+3)​​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as
well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k≥1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Prove that $x25​=x(x−2)5​−x2(x−2)10​$. [3]



Determine the set of numbers $x$ for which the proof in part (a) is valid. [2]



$$$$$$
list.markScheme:
By working out the right side of the equation, we have
$$$x(x−2)5​−x2(x−2)10​​=x2(x−2)5x​−x2(x−2)10​=x2(x−2)5x−10​=x2 (x−2)​5 (x−2)​​=x25​.​$$$


We cannot have a denominator equal to zero, and therefore
$$$x2x(x−2)x2(x−2)​=0⇒x=0[from L.H.S.]=0⇒x=0,2[from R.H.S.]=0⇒x=0,2[from R.H.S.]​$$$


Therefore the proof is valid for all values of $x$ except $x=0$ and $x=2$.
$x∈R,x=0 and x=2​$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Use the principle of mathematical induction to prove that
$$$1⋅21+2⋅22+3⋅23+⋯+n⋅2n​=2+(n−1)2n+1for all n∈Z+.​$$$
list.markScheme:
Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$1⋅21+2⋅22+3⋅23+⋯+n⋅2n=2+(n−1)2n+1[for n∈Z+]​$$$
Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.
Base case. For $n=1$, we have
$$$1⋅21​=2=2+(1−1)21+1​$$$
Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k≥1$. In other words, we assume that
$$$1⋅21+2⋅22+3⋅23+⋯+k⋅2k​=2+(k−1)2k+1(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that
$$$1⋅21+2⋅22+3⋅23+⋯+k⋅2k+(k+1)2k+1​=2+k⋅2k+2(1)​$$$
From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain
$$$​1⋅21+2⋅22+3⋅23+⋯+k⋅2k+(k+1)2k+1==[1⋅21+2⋅22+3⋅23+⋯+k⋅2k]+(k+1)2k+1=[2+(k−1)2k+1]+(k+1)2k+1[by (IH)]=2+(k−1​+k+1​)2k+1=2+(2k)2k+1=2+k⋅2k+2​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k≥1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Using the method of proof by contradiction, prove that $3​$ is
irrational.
list.markScheme:
Let's assume that it is not true that $3​$ is irrational. Then
$3​$
is rational, so there are positive integers $a$ and $b$ ($b=0$) such
that
$$$3​=ba​$$$
we can also assume that this fraction has
been written in lowest terms, so $a$ and $b$ have no common factors.
Squaring both sides,
$$$(3​)23a2​=(ba​)2=b2a2​=3b2(1)​$$$
From (1) we
deduce that $a2$ is divisible by $3$ and therefore $a$ is divisible by
$3$. Then we can write $a=3p$ for some positive integer $p$.
Substituting $a=3p$ in (1), we get
$$$(3p)29p23p2​=3b2=3b2=b2​$$$
Therefore $b$ is
also divisible by $3$. This is a contradiction, as $a$ and $b$ have no
common factors.
Thus our original assumption is false, and by the method of proof by
contradiction, we conclude $3​$ is irrational.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Let $r∈R,r=1$. Use the method of mathematical
induction to prove that
$$$1+r+r2+⋯+rn=1−r1−rn+1​for all n∈Z+.​$$$
list.markScheme:
Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$1+r+r2+⋯+rn=1−r1−rn+1​[for n∈Z+]​$$$
Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.
Base case. For $n=1$, we have
$$$1−r1−r1+1​​=1−r1−r2​=1−r​(1+r)(1−r)​​=1+r​$$$
Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k≥1$. In other words, we assume that
$$$1+r+r2+…+rk=1−r1−rk+1​(IH)​$$$
for
some $k≥1$.
Inductive step: To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that
$$$1+r+r2+…+rk+rk+1=1−r1−r(k+1)+1​(1)​$$$
From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain
$$$1+r+r2+…+rk+rk+1​=(1+r+r2+…+rk)+rk+1=1−r1−rk+1​+rk+1[by (IH)]=1−r1−rk+1​+1−rrk+1(1−r)​=1−r1−rk+1+rk+1−rk+2​=1−r1−r(k+1)+1​​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as
well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k≥1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.

list.title: Question 10
list.content: Prove by contradiction that the equation $3x3−7x2+5=0$ has no integer roots.
list.markScheme:
Assume that the equation $3x3−7x2+5=0$ has at least one integer root, $n$.
Therefore, $n$ satisfies the equation
$$$3n3−7n2+53n3+5​=0=7n2​$$$
Consider first the case where $n$ is odd. $3n3$ is odd and hence $3n3+5$ is even. $7n2$ is odd, therefore
$$$3n3+5​=7n2​$$$
Now consider the case where $n$ is even. $3n3$ is even and hence $3n3+5$ is odd. $7n2$ is even, therefore
$$$3n3+5​=7n2​$$$
We have shown that for $n∈Z$, whether $n$ is odd or even, the equation is not satisfied. Hence there is a contradiction.
Thus our original assumption is false, and by the method of proof by contradiction, we conclude that $3x3−7x2+5=0$ has no integer roots.

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
The Fibonacci sequence is defined as follows:
$$$a0​an​​=0,a1​=1,a2​=1,=an−1​+an−2​forn≥2.(FS)​$$$
Prove by mathematical induction that
$a12​+a22​+⋯+an2​=an​an+1​$, where $n∈Z+$.
list.markScheme:
Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$a12​+a22​+...+an2​=an​an+1​[for n∈Z+]​$$$
Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.
Base case. For $n=1$, we have
$$$a12​​=12=1⋅1=a1​a2​​$$$
Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k≥1$. In other words, we assume that
$$$a12​+a22​+...+ak2​=ak​ak+1​(IH)​$$$
for some
$k≥1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that
$$$a12​+a22​+...+ak2​+ak+12​=ak+1​ak+2​(1)​$$$
From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain
$$$a12​+a22​+...+ak2​+ak+12​​=(a12​+a22​+...+ak2​)+ak+12​=ak​ak+1​+ak+12​[by (IH)]=(ak​+ak+1​)ak+1​=ak+2​ak+1​[by (FS)]=ak+1​ak+2​​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k≥1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Let $y=x2ex$, for $x∈R$.


Find $dxdy​$. [1]



Prove by mathematical induction that
$$$dxndn​(x2ex)=(n(n−1)+2nx+x2)exfor all n∈Z+, n≥2.$$$
[7]
list.markScheme:
Using the product rule, we get
$$$dxdy​​=dxd​(x2ex)=2xex+x2ex​​$$$


Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$dxndn​(x2ex)=(n(n−1)+2nx+x2)ex[for n≥2]​$$$
Using induction, we will prove that P$(n)$
$holds for all n∈Z+, n≥2.$
Base case. For $n=2$, we have
$$$dx2d2​(x2ex)​=dxd​[dxd​(x2ex)]=dxd​(2xex+x2ex)[by part (a)]=2ex+2xex+2xex+x2ex​$$$
$$$​=(2+4x+x2)ex=(2(2−1)+2(2)x+x2)ex​$$$


Hence P$(2)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k≥2$. In other words, we assume that
$$$dxkdk​(x2ex)=(k(k−1)+2kx+x2)ex(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥2$.
Inductive Step: To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that
$$$dxk+1dk+1​(x2ex)=((k+1)k+2(k+1)x+x2)ex(1)​$$$
From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain
$$$dxk+1dk+1​(x2ex)​=dxd​[dxkdk​(x2ex)]=dxd​[(k(k−1)+2kx+x2)ex][by (IH)]=(2k+2x)ex+(k(k−1)+2kx+x2)ex=((k+1)k+2(k+1)x+x2)ex.​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$
holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(2)$ holds, and for every $k≥2$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that
P$(n)$ holds for all $n∈Z+,n≥2$.

list.title: Question 13
list.content: Use proof by contradiction to show that if $(n−6)3=(n+6)3−n3,n∈Z+$, is true then $n$ must be even.
list.markScheme:
First expand and simplify the given equality
$$$n3+(13​)(−6)n2+(23​)(−6)n+(−6)3n3−18n2+108n−216n3−36n2−432​=n3+(13​)(6)n2+(23​)6n+63−n3=18n2+108n+216=0​M1​$$$
Now we make the contradiction by assuming $n$ is odd. Let $n=2k+1$, where $k∈Z$
$$$hack​A1​$$$
$$$(2k+1)3−36(2k+1)2−432​=0​$$$
Consider the term $36(2k+1)2$, we can rewrite this as $2×18(2k+1)2$, therefore this term is even.
Hence we can write $36(2k+1)2$ as $2a$, where $a∈Z$.
$$$hack​R1​$$$
The term $−432$ is also even.
Let's expand the first term
$$$(2k+1)3​=8k3+12k2+6k+1=2(4k3+6k2+3k)+1=2b+1​A1​$$$
Where $b∈Z$.
Therefore the original simplified equation can be written in the following form
$$$00​=2b+1−2a−432=2(b−a−216)+1​$$$
Let $c=b−a−216$ where where $c∈Z$. Hence
$$$0​=2c+1​R1​$$$
This is a contradiction as $0$ is an even number and $2c+1$ is odd.
$$$hack​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 14
list.content: Use mathematical induction to prove that $n3−9n2+26n−24$ is divisible by $6$ for all $n≥5$.
list.markScheme:
Let $P(n)$ be the proposition that $n3−9n2+26n−24$ is divisible by $6$.
The first step is to verify the base case ($n=5$).
$$$P(5)​=(5)3−9(5)2+26(5)−24=6​$$$
$P(5)$ is divisible by $6$ therefore it is true.
$$$A1$$$
$gap$
Now we will form the assumption.
Assume $P(k)$ is true.
$$$P(k)​=k3−9k2+26k−24=6A​M1​$$$
Where $k,A∈Z+$ and $k≥5$.
Now we will consider the $(k+1)th$ case and by using the assumption we will show that $P(k+1)$ is divisible by $6$.
$$$P(k+1)​=(k+1)3−9(k+1)2+26(k+1)−24=k3+3k2+3k+1−9k2−18k−9+26k+26−24​M1​$$$
The terms in bold above are equivalent to the assumption, $P(k)$. Hence we can replace them with $6A$ and then simplify. This is known as the inductive step as we are inducting the assumption into the proof.
$$$P(k+1)​=3k2+3k+1−18k−9+26+6A=6A+3k2−15k+18​A1​$$$
We now need to show the remaining terms involving $k$ are divisible by $6$.
$$$P(k+1)​=6A+3(k−2)(k−3)​$$$
After factorising we can see that the expression $(k−2)(k−3)$ is the product of two consecutive numbers (recall $k≥5$). This will always be an even number, hence we can replace it with $2B$, Where $B∈Z+$.
$$$P(k+1)​=6A+3×2B=6A+6B=6(A+B)​$$$
$P(k+1)$ is divisible by $6$.
$$$R1$$$
$gap$
We must write a concluding sentence.
$$$P(5) is true and P(k) being true implies P(k+1) is true. We can therefore say, by the principle of mathematical induction, that P(n) is true for all n≥5.​$$$
$$$R1$$$
$gap$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Consider the function $f(x)=4x−x2−1$.

Write $f(x)$ in the form $(x−h)2+k$.[2]


A line is drawn through the points $A(0,f(0))$ and $B(2,f(2))$.




Write down the coordinates of points $A$ and $B$.


Find $g(x)$, the equation of the line passing through points $A$ and $B$.


Hence, show that the area enclosed by $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ is $34​$ units$2$. [4]





A horizontal line is drawn through the points $C(1,f(1))$ and $D(3,f(3))$.

Show that the area enclosed by $f(x)$ and line $CD$ is $34​$ units$2$.[2]


Consider the two points $E(a,f(a))$ and $F(a+2,f(a+2))$.

Show that the area enclosed by the function $f$ and the line $EF$ is $34​$ units$2$.[5]
list.markScheme:
To write $f$ in the desired form we must complete the square
$$$​(M1)​$$$
$$$f(x)​=4x−x2−1=−(x2−4x)−1=−[(x−2)2−(2)2]−1=−(x−2)2+4−1=3−(x−2)2​​A1​$$$




We can find the $y−$coordinate by evaluating the function at both $x=0$ and $x=2$.
$$$​​f(0)​=3−(0−2)2=−1​​​f(2)​=3−(2−2)2=3​​$$$
Hence the coordinates are $A(0,−1) and B(2,3)​$
$$$​A1​$$$


We can make a quick sketch of $f$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/41d8354f-4cec-4922-8437-0ca160d21c7a/images/8a3d4b08-1625-4d2d-b1a0-4194dc8e9e19/AA1290-a.JPEG)


We have the $y−$intercept already.
And the gradient of the line through $A$ and $B$ is
$$$mm​=2−03−(−1)​=2​$$$
Therefore, the line through $A$ and $B$ is $y=2x−1​$
$$$​A1​$$$


The shaded area, seen below, shows the area we need to find


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/41d8354f-4cec-4922-8437-0ca160d21c7a/images/7d705ca2-0e34-498c-9547-5edd23168ba9/AA1290-a2.JPEG)


To find the area we evaluate the following definite integral, where $Ax​$ and $Bx​$ are the $x−$coordinates of points $A$ and $B$ respectively
$$$​=∫Ax​Bx​​(f(x)−g(x))dx=∫02​(4x−x2−1−(2x−1))dx=∫02​(2x−x2)dx​M1​$$$
Using the inverse power rule and substituting in the limits we get
$$$​=[x2−31​x3]02​=(2)2−31​(2)3−((0)2−31​(0)3)=34​ units2​...as required​A1​$$$




We can make a quick sketch of the new region enclosed by $f(x)$ and the new (horizontal) $g(x)$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/41d8354f-4cec-4922-8437-0ca160d21c7a/images/93eaf720-1029-402e-8f97-65cddb8026ba/AA1290-a3.JPEG)


We now evaluate the definite integral, where $Cx​$ and $Dx​$ are the $x−$coordinates of points $C$ and $D$ respectively
$$$​=∫Cx​Dx​​(f(x)−g(x))dx=∫13​(4x−x2−1−(2))dx=∫13​(4x−x2−3)dx​M1​$$$
Using the inverse power rule, to integrate each term and substitute in the limits, we get
$$$​=[2x2−31​x3−3x]13​=2(3)2−31​(3)3−3(3)−((2(1)2−31​(1)3−3(1))=18−9−9−(2−31​−3)=34​ units2​...as required​A1​$$$


The diagram below shows a region bound by $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ and the points $E(a,f(a))$ and $F(a+2,f(a+2)))$.
The function $f$ needs to be used to calculate the $y−$coordinate values of $E$ and $F$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/41d8354f-4cec-4922-8437-0ca160d21c7a/images/7597d9d0-8ed4-4fea-8e36-94f1a14efc4c/AA1290-a4.JPEG)


To find the area we need to find the linear function $g(x)$ in terms of $a$.
$$$​(M1)​$$$
$g(x)$ is of the form $g(x)=mg​x+cg​$.
Where the gradient, $mg​$, is
$$$mg​​=x2​−x1​y2​+y1​​=a+2−af(a+2)−f(a)​=2(3−a2)−(3−(a−2)2))​​$$$
Simplifying we get
$$$mg​​=2−a2+(a−2)2​=2−a2+a2−4a+4​=2−2a​A1​$$$
Using the point $A(a,f(a))$ we can find the $y−$intercept, $cg​$, of $g(x)$
$$$yf(a)3−(a−2)2cg​cg​​=(2−2a)x+cg​=(2−2a)a+cg​=(2−2a)a+cg​=3−(a−2)2−2a+2a2=a2+2a−1​A1​$$$
The function $g(x)$ in terms of $a$ is
$$$g(x)=(2−2a)x+a2+2a−1​$$$
The shaded area is given by the following definite integral
$$$​=∫Ex​Fx​​(f(x)−g(x))dx=∫aa+2​(4x−x2−1−((2−2a)x+a2+2a−1))dx​M1​$$$
Simplifying we get
$$$​=∫aa+2​(4x−x2−1−(2x−2ax+a2+2a−1))dx=∫aa+2​(2x−x2+2ax−a2−2a)dx=∫aa+2​(−x2+(2a+2)x−a2−2a)dx​$$$
Now we can integrate each term, using the inverse power rule, and substitute in the limits.
$$$=[−31​x3+22a+2​x2−x(a2+2a)]aa+2​​A1​$$$
$$$=−31​(a+2)3+(a+1)(a+2)2−(a+2)(a2+2a)−......(−31​a3+(a+1)a2−a(a2+2a))​$$$
Expanding and simplifying we gradient
$$$=−31​(a3+6a2+12a+8)+a3+5a2+8a+4−(a3+4a2+4a)−......(−31​a3+a3+a2−a3−2a2)​$$$
We continue to collect any like terms and simplify to get
$$$=−31​a3​−2a2−4a−38​+a2+4a+4−......(−31​a3​−a2)​$$$
$$$​=−2a2​−4a−38​+a2+4a+4+a2=−38​+4=34​units2​...as required​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
Let $f(x)=(x+1)e−2x$, $x∈R$.


Find $f′(x)$. [2]



Prove by induction that
$dxndnf​=[n(−2)n−1+(−2)n(x+1)]e−2x$
for all $n∈Z+$.[7]
list.markScheme:
Using the product rule, we get
$$$f′(x)​=dxd​[(x+1)e−2x]=e−2x−2(x+1)e−2x=[1−2(x+1)]e−2x​​$$$


Let $P(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$dxndnf​=[n(−2)n−1+(−2)n(x+1)]e−2x[for n∈Z+]​$$$
Using mathematical induction, we will prove that $P(n)$
holds for all $n∈Z+$.


Base case. For $n=1$, from part (a), we have
$$$dxdf​=[1−2(x+1)]e−2x​$$$
Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that $P(k)$ holds
for some $k≥1$. In other words, we assume that
$$$dxkdkf​=[k(−2)k−1+(−2)k(x+1)]e−2x(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥1$.
Inductive step. To show that $P(k+1)$ holds, we
need to show that
$$$dxk+1dk+1f​=[(k+1)(−2)k+(−2)(k+1)(x+1)]e−2x​$$$
If we differentiate both sides of the equation (IH), we obtain
$$$dxk+1dk+1f​​=dxd​[[k(−2)k−1+(−2)k(x+1)]e−2x]=[(−2)k]e−2x−2[k(−2)k−1+(−2)k(x+1)]e−2x=[(−2)k]e−2x+[k(−2)k+(−2)k+1(x+1)]e−2x=[(k+1)(−2)k+(−2)(k+1)(x+1)]e−2x​$$$
Hence $P(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k≥1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
Using the principle of mathematical induction, prove that $n(n2+5)$ is
divisible by $6$ for all integers $n≥1$.
list.markScheme:
Notation: For $m,n∈Z$, $m∣n$ means $m$ divides $n$ or
$n$ is divisible by $m$.
Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$6∣n(n2+5)[for n≥1]​$$$
Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.
Base case. For $n=1$, we have
$$$6∣(1)(12+5)=6​$$$
Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k≥1$. In other words, we assume that
$$$6∣k(k2+5)(IH)​$$$
for some
$k≥1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that
$$$6∣(k+1)[(k+1)2+5](1)​$$$
If we rewrite the expression on the right hand side of the statement
$(1)$, we obtain
$$$(k+1)[(k+1)2+5]​=(k+1)[(k2+5)+(2k+1)]=k(k2+5)+(k2+5)+(k+1)(2k+1)=k(k2+5)+(3k2+3k+6)=k(k2+5)+3[k(k+1)+2](2)​$$$
Since either $k$ or $k+1$ is even, $k(k+1)$ is divisible by $2$.
Hence we deduce
$$$2666​∣k(k+1)+2∣3[k(k+1)+2]∣k(k2+5)+3[k(k+1)+2][by (IH)]∣(k+1)[(k+1)2+5][by (2)]​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k≥1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
Solve the inequality $x2≥2x+3$. [2]



Use mathematical induction to prove that $2n>n2−2$ for all
$n∈Z+$, $n≥3$.[6]
list.markScheme:
If we draw the graphs of $y=x2$ and $y=2x+3$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2657c2a5-86af-44db-8be4-bfd4d027e790/images/2ce2fde1-d607-4fa0-9109-01ca871a4538/8559be520206e999f46f83d313584ee1a94282b7.svg)


Using the $x$-coordinates of A and B, we see that the graph of
$y=x2$ is above the graph of $y=2x+3$ when $x<−1$ and
$x>3$, and the graphs intersect at $x=−1,3$.
Hence the solution set to the inequality $x2≥2x+3$ is
$(−∞,−1]∪[3,∞)​$


Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$2n​>n2−2[for n≥3]​$$$


Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$, $n≥3$.
Base case. For $n=3$, we have
$$$23=8​>32−2=7​$$$
Hence P$(3)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k≥3$. In other words, we assume that
$$$2k​>k2−2(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥3$.
Inductive step: To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that
$$$2k+1​>(k+1)2−2(1)​$$$
From the
left hand side of the inequality $(1)$, we obtain
$$$2k+1[by part (a)]​=2⋅2k>2[k2−2][by (IH)]=k2+[k2−4]≥2k+3+[k2−4]=[k2+2k+1]−2=(k+1)2−2​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(3)$ holds, and for every $k≥3$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that
P$(n)$ holds for all $n∈Z+,n≥3$.

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
Use mathematical induction to prove that
$$$2n×cosx×cos2x×cos4x×...×cos2n−1x​=sinxsin2nx​​$$$
where $n∈Z+$. [4]





Find the first two non-zero terms of the Maclaurin series for $sin8x$.


Hence find the first two non-zero terms of the Maclaurin series for $sinxsin8x​$.


Hence find an estimate for $∫00.1​cosxcos2xcos4xdx$.[12]
list.markScheme:
We start by showing the base case is true.
This is when $n=1$.
Let's first consider the value of the L.H.S. of the proposition
$$$21×cos21−1x​=2cosx​$$$
And the value of the R.H.S. is
$$$sinxsin21x​​=sinx2sinxcosx​=2cosx=L.H.S.​R1​$$$
Hence we have shown the proposition is true when $n=1$.
The next step is to assume the proposition is true when $n=k$ where $k∈Z+$
$$$2k×cosx×cos2x×cos4x×...×cos2k−1x​=sinxsin2kx​​$$$
Next we need to use the assumption to show that the proposition is true  when $n=k+1$.
Hence we need to prove
$$$2k+1×cosx×cos2x×cos4x×...×cos2kx​=sinxsin2k+1x​​M1​$$$
Let's start by rewriting the L.H.S. so it looks similar to the L.H.S. of the assumption
$$$L.H.S.​=2×2k×cosx×cos2x×cos4x×...×cos2k−1x×cos2kx​$$$
Notice the blue part is now the same as the L.H.S. of the assumption, hence we can replace it with the R.H.S. of the assumption
$$$​=2(sinxsin2kx​)×cos2kx​A1​$$$
This is known as the inductive step.
We can rearrange the trigonometric identity $sin2θ=2sinθcosθ$ to
$$$sinθcosθ​=21​sin2θ​$$$
and use it to rewrite our L.H.S. giving
$$$​=2×sinxsin2kx​×cos2kx=2×sinx21​sin(2×2kx)​=sinxsin(2×2kx)​=sinxsin2k+1x​​...as required.=R.H.S.​A1​$$$
We have shown the proposition is true when $n=1$ and we have shown it to be true when $n=k+1$, assuming $n=k$ is true. Therefore by the principle of mathematical induction the proposition is true for all positive integer values of $n$.




We begin by noting that $sin8x$ is a composite function.
Hence we can use the formula for the Macluarin series for sine but replace $x$ with $8x$.
$$$sinxsin8x​=x−3!x3​+5!x5​−...=8x−3!(8x)3​​(M1)​$$$
We only need the first two non-zero terms hence we get
$$$​=8x−6512x3​=8x−3256​x3​​A1​$$$


Let's begin by using a general power series to represent the result of the quotient
$$$sinxsin8x​​=a0​+a1​x+a2​x2+a3​x3+...​$$$
Where $ai​$ are real numbers we must determine.
We can use the result from part (a) and the general formula for sine to write the numerator and denominator as a Maclaurin series up to the $x3$ term
$$$x−3!x3​8x−3256​x3​​=a0​+a1​x+a2​x2+a3​x3+...​$$$
Recall, we only need the first two non-zero terms which will mean up to and including the $x3$ term.
It can be challenging to attempt to use long division to rewrite the L.H.S. Often a better strategy, when facing problems like this, is to rewrite the division as a multiplication
$$$8x−3256​x3​=(x−3!x3​)(a0​+a1​x+a2​x2+a3​x3+...)​(M1)​$$$
We can now expand the R.H.S. until we have all of the terms required to give the $x$ and $x3$ terms.
$$$8x−3256​x3​=a0​x−6a0​x3​+a1​x2​−6a1​x4​​+a2​x3−6a2​x5​​=a0​x−6a0​x3​++a2​x3​A1​$$$
There is no $x2$ term therefore $a1​$ must be zero. Also we don't need any power of $x$ higher than $3$. So we can cancel out another two terms.
We can now equate the coefficients of the $x−$terms on the left and right side giving
$$$8−3256​​=a0​for x=−6a0​​+a2​for x3​A1​$$$
We can see that $a0​=8$ hence we can use this to find $a2​$
$$$−3256​−5126a2​a2​​=−68​+a2​=−68​+66a2​​=−8+6a2​=−504=−84​(M1)A1​$$$
Therefore, referring back to the series expansion at the start of the solution, we can see that the first two non-zero terms are
$$$sinxsin8x​​=a0​+a1​x+a2​x2+a3​x3+...=8−84x2​​A1​$$$


The integral given is a very difficult integral to perform directly.
However, notice that it is of the form of the proposition from part (a).
If we take the proposition and let $n=3$ we get
$$$23×cosx×cos2x×cos4xcosx×cos2x×cos4x​=sinxsin23x​=8sinxsin8x​​(A1)​$$$
Hence we can rewrite the integral as
$$$∫00.1​cosxcos2xcos4xdx​=∫00.1​8sinxsin8x​dx=81​∫00.1​sinxsin8x​dx​(A1)​$$$
The result is still a difficult integral to perform but the key word in the question is estimate. This suggests we should use the series expansion from part (b)(ii).
Hence we get
$$$∫00.1​cosxcos2xcos4xdx​≈81​∫00.1​(8−84x2)dx​$$$
Integrating each term we get
$$$​=81​[8x−28x3]00.1​​A1​$$$
Substituting in the limits we get
$$$​=81​(8(0.1)−28(0.1)3)=0.1−3.5×0.001=0.1−0.0035=0.0965​​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
Show that
$2n+1​1​<n+1​−n​$,
where $n∈Z,n≥0$. [3]



Hence show that $2​1​<22​−2$.
[2]



Prove by mathematical induction that
$$$r=2∑n​r​1​<2n​−2for all n∈Z+, n≥2.$$$
[9]
list.markScheme:
For any $n∈Z,n≥0$, we have
$$$n+1​−n​​=[1n+1​−n​​][n+1​+n​n+1​+n​​]=n+1​+n​(n​+1)−n​​=n+1​+n​1​​$$$
Hence we get
$$$2n+1​1​<n+1​+n​1​[since n+1​>n​]​$$$
$$$2n+1​1​<n+1​−n​​(1)$$$


Hence, substituting $n=1$ in the inequality $(1)$, we obtain
$$$22​1​​<2​−1​$$$
$$$2​1​<22​−2​$$$


Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$r=2∑n​r​1​<2n​−2[for n≥2]​$$$
Using math induction, we will prove that P$(n)$
$holds for all n∈Z+, n≥2.$
Base case. For $n=2$, from part (b), we have
$$$2​1​<22​−2​$$$
Hence P$(2)$
holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for
some $k≥2$. In other words, we assume that
$$$r=2∑k​r​1​<2k​−2(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥2$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need
to show that
$$$r=2∑k+1​r​1​<2k+1​−2(2)​$$$


From the left hand side of the inequality $(2)$, we obtain
$$$r=2∑k+1​r​1​​=k+1​1​+r=2∑k​r​1​<k+1​1​+(2k​−2)[by (IH)]<(2k+1​−2k​​)+(2k​​−2)[by part (a)]=2k+1​−2​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(2)$ holds, and for every $k≥2$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that
P$(n)$ holds for all $n∈Z+,n≥2$.

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
This question asks you to explore the sequence defined by
$$$un​=63​​(αn−βn)$$$
where $α$ and $β$
are the roots of the quadratic equation $x2−4x+1=0,α>β$
and $n∈Z+$.


Find the value of $α$ and the value of $β$. Give your answers in the form $a±b​$, where $a,b∈Z+$.[3]



Hence find the values of $u1​$ and $u2​$. [4]



Show that $α2=4α−1$ and $β2=4β−1$. [1]



Hence show that $un+2​=4un+1​−un​$.[4]



Suppose that $un​$ and $un+1​$ are integers. Show that $un+2​$ is also an integer.[2]



Hence show that $un​$ is an integer for all $n∈Z+$.[2]



Now consider the sequence defined by
$$$vn​=63​​(αn+βn).$$$


Find the exact values of $v1​$ and $v2​$.[4]



Express $vn+2​$ in terms of $vn+1​$ and $vn​$.[4]



Hence show that $vn​$ is a multiple of $33​​$ for all $n∈Z+$.[4]
list.markScheme:
Completing the square for $x2−4x+1=0$ we have
$$$(x−2)2−3(x−2)2x−2x​=0=3=±3​=2±3​​$$$
Given that $α>β$, we have $α=2+3​ and β=2−3​​$


We have
$$$u1​u2​​=63​​(α−β)=63​​(2+3​−(2−3​))u1​=1​[By using G.D.C.]=63​​(α2−β2)=63​​((2+3​)2−(2−3​)2)u2​=4​[By using G.D.C.]​$$$


Given that $α$ is a root of the quadratic equation, we get
$$$α2−4α+1​=0α2=4α−1​​$$$
Similarly
$$$β2−4β+1​=0β2=4β−1​​$$$


Using the expressions from part (c), we get
$$$un+2​​=63​​(αn+2−βn+2)=63​​(αnα2−βnβ2)=63​​(αn(4α−1)−βn(4β−1))=63​​(4αn+1−αn−4βn+1+βn)=63​​(4(αn+1−βn+1)−(αn−βn))=643​​(αn+1−βn+1)−63​​(αn−βn)un+2​=4un+1​−un​​​$$$


Using the results from part (d), we get
$$$un​ and un+1​−un​ and 4un+1​4un+1​−un​​ are integers are integers is an integerun+2​ is an integer​​$$$


Using part (e), we get
$$$u1​u2​u3​un​​=1 is an integer (by part (b))=4 is an integer (by part (b)) is an integer (by part (e))⋮ is an integer (by part (e))​​$$$
Hence,$we conclude that un​ is an integer for all n∈Z+.​$


We have
$$$v1​v2​​=63​​(α+β)=63​​(2+3​+2−3​)v1​=323​​​=63​​(α2+β2)=63​​((2+3​)2+(2−3​)2)=63​​(4+43​+3+4−43​+3)v2​=373​​​​$$$


By a procedure similar to part (d), we get
$$$vn+2​​=63​​(αn+2+βn+2)=63​​(αnα2+βnβ2)​$$$
From part (c) we have $α2=4α−1$ and $β2=β−1$.
$$$vn+2​​=63​​(αn(4α−1)+βn(4β−1))=63​​(4αn+1−αn+4βn+1−βn)=63​​(4(αn+1+βn+1)−(αn+βn))=643​​(αn+1+βn+1)−63​​(αn+βn)vn+2​=4vn+1​−vn​​​$$$


First suppose that $vn​$ and $vn+1​$ are both multiples of $33​​$. Let $vn​=3p3​​$ and $vn+1​=3q3​​$ where $p,q∈Z$. Using the result from part (h), we have
$$$vn+2​​=34q3​​−3p3​​=(4q−p)33​​​$$$
If $vn​$ and $vn+1​$ are both multiples of $33​​$, then $vn+2​$ is also. From part (g) we notice that $v1​$ and $v2​$ are both multiples of $33​​$.
Therefore,$vn​ is a multiple of 33​​ for all n∈Z+​$

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
This question asks you to investigate some properties of hexagonal
numbers.
Hexagonal numbers can be represented by dots as shown below where $hn​$
denotes the $n$th hexagonal number,
$n∈N$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f04773c8-5027-4b36-ab13-ded60788d8d3/images/4d8392bc-6e52-4566-b47d-6f63c2090a5b/b2b46cf7a1e76fe3e94b0c5adbb806ad8bd4f38f.svg)


Note that $6$ points are required to create the regular hexagon $h2​$
with side of length $1$, while $15$ points are required to create the
next hexagon $h3​$ with side of length $2$, and so
on.


Write down the value of $h5​$.[1]



By examining the pattern, show that $hn+1​=hn​+4n+1$,
$n∈N$. [3]



By expressing $hn​$ as a series, show that $hn​=2n2−n$,
$n∈N$.[3]



Hence, determine whether $2016$ is a hexagonal number.[3]



Find the least hexagonal number which is greater than
$80000$.[5]



Consider the statement:
$45$ is the only hexagonal number which is divisible by $9$.
Show that this statement is false.[2]



Matt claims that given $h1​=1$ and $hn+1​=hn​+4n+1$,
$n∈N$, then
$$$hn​​=2n2−n,n∈N.​$$$

Show, by mathematical induction, that Matt's claim is true
for all $n∈N$.[7]
list.markScheme:
$45​$


We have
$$$h2​h3​h4​h5​​=h1​+5=h2​+9=h3​+13=h4​+17​$$$
And therefore
$$$hn+1​​=hn​+un​​$$$
Where $un​$ is the $n$th term of an arithmetic sequence with first term $u1​=5$ and common difference $d=4$.
Using the formula for the $n$th term of an arithmetic sequence, we have
$$$un​un​​=u1​+(n−1)d=5+4(n−1)=4n+1​$$$
Hence
$$$​hn+1​=hn​+4n+1​​$$$


Using part (b), we get
$$$h1​h2​h3​h4​hn​​=1=1+u1​=1+u1​+u2​=1+u1​+u2​+u3​⋮=1+u1​+⋯+un−1​​$$$
Hence, the general term can be obtained by using the formula for the sum of an arithmetic series
$$$hn​​=1+Sn−1​=1+2n−1​[u1​+un−1​]=1+2n−1​[5+5+4(n−2)]=1+2n−1​[4n+2]=1+2n−1​[2(2n+1)]=1+(n−1)(2n+1)=1+2n2−n−1=2n2−n​​$$$


We attempt to solve $hn​=2016$ for some $n∈N$ as
follows
$$$hn​2n2−n2n2−n−2016n​=2016=2016=0=32[by using G.D.C.]​$$$
Therefore,$2016 is the 32nd hexagonal number​$


We solve the inequality $hn​>80000$ as follows
$$$hn​2n2−n2n2−n−80000n​>80000>80000>0>200.25[by using G.D.C.]​$$$
Therefore, the first hexagonal number greater than
$80000$ is
$$$h201​​=2(2012)−201=80601​​$$$


Observe that the general term of an hexagonal number can be written
as
$$$hn​​=n(2n−1)​$$$
Hence, every hexagonal number
$hn​$ is divisible by $n$, so we can easily produce another
hexagonal number divisible by $9$, for example
$$$h9​​=2(92)−9=2(81)−9=153​$$$
$Therefore, the statement is false.​$


Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$hn​​=2n2−n,[for n∈N]​$$$
Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n∈N$.
Base case. For $n=1$, we have
$$$h1​​=1=2(1)2−1​$$$
Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for
some $k≥1$. In other words, we assume that
$$$hk​​=2k2−k(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need
to show that
$$$hk+1​​=2(k+1)2−(k+1)(1)​$$$
From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain
$$$hk+1​​=hk​+(4k+1)=2k2−k+(4k+1)[by (IH)]=2k2+3k+1=2(k2+2k+1)−(k+1)=2(k+1)2−(k+1)​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion.
P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k≥1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
$Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P(n) holds for all n∈N.​$

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
Use de Moivre's theorem to find the value of
$[cos(6π​)+isin(6π​)]12$.
[2]



Use mathematical induction to prove that
$$$(cosα−isinα)n=cos(nα)−isin(nα)for all n∈Z+.$$$
[6]



Let
$w=cosα+isinα$.


Find an expression in terms of $α$ for
$wn−(w∗)n$, $n∈Z+$, where $w∗$ is
the complex conjugate of $w$. [2]





Show that $ww∗=1$.


Write down and simplify the binomial expansion of
$(w−w∗)3$ in terms of $w$ and $w∗$.


Hence show that
$sin(3α)=3sinα−4sin3α$. [5]





Hence solve
$4sin3α+(2cosα−3)sinα=0$ for
$0≤α≤π$. [6]
list.markScheme:
Using de Moivre's theorem, we find
$$$[cos(6π​)+isin(6π​)]12​=cos(612π​)+isin(612π​)=cos2π+isin2π=1​​$$$


Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$(cosα−isinα)n=cos(nα)−isin(nα)[for n∈Z+]​$$$
Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n∈Z+$.


Base case. For $n=1$, we have
$$$(cosα−isinα)1​=cosα−isinα=cos(1⋅α)−isin(1⋅α)​$$$
Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k≥1$. In other words, we assume that
$$$(cosα−isinα)k=cos(kα)−isin(kα)(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that
$$$(cosα−isinα)k+1=cos((k+1)α)−isin((k+1)α)(1)​$$$
From the left hand side of the equation $(1)$, we obtain
$$$​(cosα−isinα)k+1==(cosα−isinα)kcosα−(cosα−isinα)k(isinα)=[cos(kα)−isin(kα)]cosα−[cos(kα)−isin(kα)](isinα)[by (IH)]=cos(kα)cosα−isin(kα)cosα−icos(kα)sinα−sin(kα)sinα=[cos(kα)cosα−sin(kα)sinα]−i[sin(kα)cosα+cos(kα)sinα]=cos((k+1)α)−isin((k+1)α)[by compound angle formulas]​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k≥1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.


Using de Moivre's theorem and the identity $(2)$ from part
(b), we find
$$$wn−(w∗)n​=(cosα+isinα)n−(cosα−isinα)n=[cos(nα)+isin(nα)]−[cos(nα)−isin(nα)]=2isin(nα)​(3)​$$$




The product of $w$ and its conjugate is
$$$ww∗​=(cosα+isinα)(cosα−isinα)=cos2α−icosαsinα+isinαcosα+sin2α=cos2α+sin2α=1​​$$$


If we simplify the binomial expansion of $(w−w∗)3$, we
get
$$$(w−w∗)3​=w3−3w2w∗+3w(w∗)2−(w∗)3=w3−3w(ww∗)+3w∗(ww∗)−(w∗)3=w3−3w+3w∗−(w∗)3[by part (d) (i)]=w3−(w∗)3−3(w−w∗)​​$$$


Substituting $n=1$ and $n=3$ in the identity $(3)$ from part
(c), we have
$$$n=1n=3​:w−(w∗)=2isinα:w3−(w∗)3=2isin(3α)​$$$
Hence, from part d (ii), we obtain
$$$(w−w∗)3(2isinα)3−8isin3α4sin3α​=w3−(w∗)3−3(w−w∗)=2isin(3α)−3(2isinα)=2isin(3α)−6isinα=−sin(3α)+3sinα​$$$
$$$sin(3α)=3sinα−4sin3α​$$$




If we rewrite the given equation, we have
$$$4sin3α+(2cosα−3)sinα2sinαcosαsin(2α)​=0=3sinα−4sin3α=sin(3α)[by part (d) (iii)](4)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(4)$ for $α$, we find
$$$αα​=0or3α=kπ−2α[where k is an odd integer]=0orα=5kπ​[where k=1,3,5 since α∈[0,π]]​$$$
$$$α=0,5π​,53π​,π​$$$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
Let $f(x)=(x−1)e3x​$, for $x∈R$.


Find $f′(x)$.  [2]



Prove by induction that
$dxndnf​=(3n3n+x−1​)e3x​$
for all $n∈Z+$.  [7]



Find the coordinates of any local maximum and minimum points on the
graph of $y=f(x)$. Justify whether such point is a maximum or a
minimum. [5]



Find the coordinates of any points of inflexion on the graph of
$y=f(x)$. Justify whether such point is a point of inflexion.
[5]



Hence sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$, indicating clearly the points
found in parts (c) and (d) and any intercepts with the axes.
[4]
list.markScheme:
Using the product rule, we get
$$$f′(x)​=dxd​[(x−1)e3x​]=e3x​+31​(x−1)e3x​=(3x+2​)e3x​​​$$$


Let P$(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$dxndnf​=(3n3n+x−1​)e3x​[for n∈Z+]​$$$
Using mathematical induction, we will prove that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n∈Z+$.


Base case. For $n=1$, from part (a), we have
$$$dxdf​=(33+x−1​)e3x​​$$$
Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that P$(k)$ holds for some
$k≥1$. In other words, we assume that
$$$dxkdkf​=(3k3k+x−1​)e3x​(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥1$.
Inductive step. To show that P$(k+1)$ holds, we need to
show that
$$$dxk+1dk+1f​=[3k+13(k+1)+x−1​]e3x​​$$$
If we differentiate both sides of the equation (IH), we obtain
$$$dxk+1dk+1f​​=dxd​[(3k3k+x−1​)e3x​]=(3k1​)e3x​+31​(3k3k+x−1​)e3x​=[3k1​+3k+13k+x−1​]e3x​=[3k+13(k+1)+x−1​]e3x​​$$$
Hence P$(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k≥1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for all
$n∈Z+$.


If we solve the equation $f′(x)=0$ for $x$, we get
$$$(3x+2​)e3x​x+2x​=0=0=−2​$$$
Hence $−2$ is the only critical number of
$f$.
Using the ID Test, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3446dd1a-9a13-43e5-8af3-ee3cf0e76f4c/images/6df8b040-2aba-4405-8103-6cc64148c86f/41f59f91431e030c029eab143139497c30f1df01.svg)


The sign of $f′$ changes from negative to positive at $−2$.
Hence, by the First Derivative Test, $f$ has a local minimum at
$−2$.
Evaluating $y=f(x)$ for $x=−2$, we find
$$$y​=f(−2)=(−2−1)e−32​=−3e−32​​$$$
Hence the graph of $y=f(x)$
has a local minimum at
$A(−2,−3e−32​)​$.


If we solve the equation $f′′(x)=0$ for $x$, we get
$$$[323(2)+x−1​]e3x​3(2)+x−1x​=0=0=−5​$$$
Hence there is at most one point of inflexion
on the graph of $y=f(x)$.
Using the Concavity Test, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3446dd1a-9a13-43e5-8af3-ee3cf0e76f4c/images/44ae7137-2675-4b13-8b95-c1dd8eee70fc/1c4ca00263d0aa013c934479ae539a797857f949.svg)


The graph of $y=f(x)$ changes concavity from downward to upward at
$−5$.
Hence the graph of $y=f(x)$ has an inflexion point at $−5$.
Evaluating $y=f(x)$ for $x=−5$, we find
$$$y​=f(−5)=(−5−1)e−35​=−6e−35​​$$$
Hence the graph of $y=f(x)$
has the inflexion point at
$B(−5,−6e−35​)​$.


We first note that the domain of the function
$f(x)=(x−1)e3x​$ is $(−∞,∞)$.
Solving the equation $f(x)=0$ for $x$, we get
$$$(x−1)e3x​x−1x​=0=0=1​$$$
Hence the point
$C(1,0)​$
is the $x$-intercept of the graph of $y=f(x)$.
Evaluating $y=f(x)$ for $x=0$, we find
$$$y​=f(0)=(0−1)e0=−1​$$$
Hence the point
$D(0,−1)​$
is the $y$-intercept of the graph of $y=f(x)$.
We have
$$$x→−∞lim​f(x)​=x→−∞lim​[(x−1)e3x​]=0​$$$
and
$$$x→∞lim​f(x)​=x→∞lim​[(x−1)e3x​]=∞​$$$
Hence the $x$-axis is a horizontal
asymptote of the graph of $y=f(x)$.
If we sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$ indicating the points A, B, C &
D, we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3446dd1a-9a13-43e5-8af3-ee3cf0e76f4c/images/42de9ed9-4fa4-4579-a350-33bfc21dab44/2fc0df9fcb42d39dca43193d481d73ca1795c4bb.svg)

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
Let $f(x)=1−x​1​$,$x<1$.


Show that $f′′(x)=43​(1−x)2−5​$. [3]



Use mathematical induction to prove that[9]

$$$f(n)(x)=(41​)nn!(2n)!​(1−x)2−1​−nn∈Z,n≥2.$$$


Let $g(x)=cos(mx)$, $m∈Q$.
Consider the function $h$ defined by $h(x)=f(x)×g(x)$ for $x<1$.
The $x2$ term in the Maclaurin series for $h(x)$ has a coefficient of
$−43​$.

Find the possible values of $m$.[9]
list.markScheme:
Taking the derivative with respect to $x$ twice, we get
$$$f′(x)f′′(x)​=dxd​(1−x)2−1​=21​(1−x)2−3​=dxd​[21​(1−x)2−3​]=43​(1−x)2−5​​​$$$


Let $P(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$dxndnf​=(41​)nn!(2n)!​(1−x)2−1​−n[for n∈Z,n≥2]​$$$
Using mathematical induction, we will prove that $P(n)$
holds for all $n∈Z$, $n≥2$.
Base case. For $n=2$, from part (a), we have
$$$dx2d2f​=43​(1−x)2−5​​$$$
Hence P$(2)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that $P(k)$
holds for some $k≥2$. In other words, we assume that
$$$dxkdkf​=(41​)kk!(2k)!​(1−x)2−1​−k(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥2$.
Inductive step. To show that $P(k+1)$ holds,
we need to show that
$$$dxk+1dk+1f​=(41​)k+1(k+1)!(2k+2)!​(1−x)2−1​−k−1​$$$
If we differentiate both sides of the equation (IH), we obtain
$$$dxk+1dk+1f​​=dxd​[(41​)kk!(2k)!​(1−x)2−1​−k]=(41​)kk!(2k)!​(k+21​)(1−x)2−1​−k−1=(41​)k+1k!(2k)!​(4k+2)(1−x)2−1​−k−1=(41​)k+1k!(2k)!​(k+1(2k+2)(2k+1)​)(1−x)2−1​−k−1=(41​)k+1(k+1)!(2k+2)!​(1−x)2−1​−k−1​$$$
Hence $P(k+1)$ holds as well.
Conclusion. P$(2)$ holds, and for every $k≥2$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n∈Z$, $n≥2$.


First, we obtain the second derivative of $h$, using the product
rule, we get
$$$h′(x)h′′(x)h′′(0)​=dxd​[f(x)×g(x)]=f′(x)g(x)+f(x)g′(x)=dxd​[f′(x)g(x)+f(x)g′(x)]=f′′(x)g(x)+2f′(x)g′(x)+f(x)g′′(x)=f′′(0)g(0)+2f′(0)g′(0)+f(0)g′′(0)(1)​$$$
From part (a), we have the following evaluations at $x=0$
$$$f(x)f′(x)f′′(x)​=1−x​1​=21​(1−x)−3/2=43​(1−x)−5/2​f(0)f′(0)f′′(0)​=1=21​=43​​$$$
and the respective evaluations for $g(x)$ and its derivatives are
$$$g(x)g′(x)g′′(x)​=cos(mx)=−msin(mx)=−m2cos(mx)​g(0)g′(0)g′′(0)​=1=0=−m2​$$$
Hence, substituting the respective values into equation (1), we get
$$$h′′(0)​=(43​)(1)+2(21​)(0)+(1)(−m2)=43​−m2​$$$
Finally, using the formula
for the $x2$ term in the Maclaurin series of $h(x)$, we obtain
$$$2h′′(0)​43​−m2m2​=−43​=−46​=49​m=±23​​​$$$

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
The following diagram shows the graph of
$y=arctan(2x−3)+43π​$ for $x∈R$,
with asymptotes at $y=4π​$ and $y=45π​$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/94f32658-f1f8-4e8a-a7ec-64540cbb0149/images/f7349dc1-1bf4-4e25-a560-7f6b11100f20/081334c23d135e25efc729fff5cf10e0f4fe7363.svg)




Describe a sequence of transformations that transforms the graph of
$y=arctanx$ to the graph of $y=arctan(2x−3)+43π​$ for
$x∈R$.[3]



Show that
$arctanp−arctanq≡arctan(1+pqp−q​)$.[3]



Verify that
$arctan(x+2)−arctan(x+1)=arctan((x+1)2+(x+1)+11​)$.[3]



Using mathematical induction and the results from part (b) and
(c), prove that[8]

$$$r=1∑n​arctan(r2+r+11​)=arctan(n+1)−4π​for n∈Z+.$$$
list.markScheme:
The function can be expressed as
$y=arctan(2(x−23​))+43π​$,
hence we get the following transformations in order
$$$transformation 1transformation 2transformation 3​:horizontal stretch by a factor of 21​​:horizontal translation 23​ units right​:vertical translation 43π​ units up​​$$$
Note that the vertical shift, which is transformation $3$, can also be performed before the horizontal transformations.


Using the compound angle identity, we get
$$$tan(arctanp−arctanq)Finally, taking the arctan on both sides​=1+tan(arctanp)tan(arctanq)tan(arctanp)−tan(arctanq)​=1+pqp−q​arctanp−arctanq≡arctan(1+pqp−q​)​​$$$


Using the formula from part (b), we obtain
$$$arctan(x+2)−arctan(x+1)​=arctan(1+(x+2)(x+1)(x+2)−(x+1)​)=arctan(((x+1)+1)(x+1)+11​)=arctan((x+1)2+(x+1)+11​)​​$$$


Let $P(n)$ be the following statement:
$$$r=1∑n​arctan(r2+r+11​)​=arctan(n+1)−4π​[for all n∈Z+]​$$$
Using mathematical induction, we will prove that $P(n)$
holds for all $n∈Z+$.
Base case. For $n=1$, from part (a), we have
$$$arctan((1)2+1+11​)​=arctan(31​)=arctan(2)−arctan(1)[by part (b,c)]=arctan(2)−4π​​$$$
Hence P$(1)$ holds.
Inductive hypothesis. We assume that $P(k)$
holds for some $k≥1$. In other words, we assume that
$$$r=1∑k​arctan(r2+r+11​)=arctan(k+1)−4π​(IH)​$$$
for some $k≥1$.
Inductive step. To show that $P(k+1)$ holds,
we need to show that
$$$r=1∑k+1​arctan(r2+r+11​)=arctan(k+2)−4π​​$$$
If we add the $k+1$ term to both sides of the equation (IH), we
obtain
$$$r=1∑k+1​arctan(r2+r+11​)[by part (c)]​=arctan(k+1)−4π​+arctan((k+1)2+(k+1)+11​)=arctan(k+2)−arctan(k+1)+arctan(k+1)−4π​=arctan(k+2)−4π​​$$$
Hence $P(k+1)$ holds
as well.
Conclusion. P$(1)$ holds, and for every $k≥1$, if
P$(k)$ holds then P$(k+1)$ also holds.
Hence, by mathematical induction, we conclude that P$(n)$ holds for
all $n∈Z+$.
